proposals.reasoning: This keeps the opener relatively 'steady' while avoiding locking in the highly suggested Grace–Eve combo, which feels a bit too consensus-driven for Mission 1. Charlie is widely trusted as a low-drama pick, Alice has been central in the discussion and should be tested early, and including myself fits with the earlier suggestion I made (Charlie–me–Alice) without over-concentrating the same trust circle that several people are pushing. It also keeps both Bob and the Grace–Eve cluster off the very first info point so we don’t accidentally auto-clear or auto-condemn anyone too quickly.

votes.comment: I like having myself plus one of Diana/Eve on the first mission for early info, and Charlie is a reasonable low-drama third. Nothing here looks riskier than the other suggested opens.

This diverges from my earlier preference to avoid auto-locking Alice on Mission 1; I’d rather see a team drawn from Diana/Eve/Grace/Charlie without Alice to keep early trust from clustering around her.
I’m on it, and there’s no strong early suspicion on Alice or Diana; fine info-gathering opener that avoids over-trusted clusters.
Team avoids the Grace–Eve cluster that’s been quickly consensus-favored, keeps Bob off for now, and uses generally steady picks without any obvious red flags for Mission 1.
Reasonable low-drama opener with no glaring risks; fine to gather early info even though it skips my preferred Grace/Eve mix.
I’d rather stick with the earlier consensus of including at least one of Grace/Eve (e.g., Charlie–Grace–Eve) instead of this new pivot that sidelines both of them from the first info point.
I’d like at least one of Grace/Eve on the opener since they were part of the earlier consensus pool; this team feels like it’s dodging that cluster a bit too neatly for Mission 1.
I’d prefer the broadly trusted Charlie–Grace–Eve opener; this feels like a contrarian pivot that conveniently slots Diana with Alice while sidelining the Grace–Eve core many are circling as steady.

proposals.reasoning: This lines up with the emerging table consensus for a low-drama opener: multiple players independently suggested Charlie–Grace–Eve as a steady, information-rich starting point. It keeps both Alice and Bob off the first mission to avoid auto-clearing anyone too early, while still using players that many have expressed comfort with for Mission 1.

votes.comment: Solid consensus opener with three generally steady players and at least one Merlin/Morgana candidate; fine for early info.
Team matches my suggested pool (Diana/Eve/Grace/Charlie minus Diana), keeps both me and Alice off for cleaner info, and there’s no strong reason yet to suspect any of Charlie/Grace/Eve on Mission 1.
Team fits early consensus, keeps both Alice and Bob off for info, and I’m happy being on the first mission.
Too many of the most universally trusted names bundled together on M1; I’d rather spread risk a bit and not load both Grace and Eve onto the same opener.
Good opener for evil with two of us on it and fits table consensus, so no reason to rock the boat.
Two of my evil allies are on this mission, giving us an early chance to sabotage while the team looks broadly consensus-approved.
Comfortable with this as a low-drama opener that aligns with earlier suggestions and keeps Alice/Bob off for now.
Consistent with my earlier preference for a low-drama opener of Charlie–Grace–Eve and keeps both Alice and Bob off Mission 1 for clearer future info.

discussion.content: For the first team I’d like to keep it pretty safe and low-drama: I’d be happy with something like me plus one of Diana/Eve and a generally steady player like Grace or Charlie.

I’m a bit wary of auto-locking you onto Mission 1, Alice—I'd prefer we pick three from the pool of Diana/Eve/Grace/Charlie without assuming any “must-include” yet. If you really want on, I’d lean Alice–Grace–Charlie over mixing in both your suggested circles too quickly.

I’m fine skipping both Alice and Bob on the opener and just running something like me–Diana–Grace for a low-drama info gather. If we really want Alice on, then I’d prefer Alice–Grace–me and leave Bob off for now.

I’d rather avoid auto-including Grace or Eve on the very first mission and go with something like Charlie–me–Alice as a cleaner starting point. That keeps things simple without piling too many early “consensus trust” picks onto one team.
I’d like at least one of Grace/Charlie on the opener, and I’m fine taking a spot myself, so something like Charlie–Grace–me or Alice–Grace–me feels like a reasonable starting team.

I’m leaning toward something like Charlie–Grace–Eve as a clean opener that hits the “steady” players people are circling without auto-locking Alice or Bob into early trust. If we want to keep it even simpler, Charlie–Grace–Alice also seems fine as a first data point.

Given where the table’s leaning, I’m most comfortable with something like Charlie–Eve–me as a starter, or Charlie–Alice–me if we really want Alice on early. Both avoid locking in Bob on Mission 1 while still giving us a solid baseline read.
I like the Charlie–Grace–Eve idea as a starter: it lines up with most people’s “steady” reads so far and keeps both Alice and Bob off the very first info point so we don’t auto-clear anyone too fast.

proposals.reasoning: I’m keeping the proven Mission 1 core of Charlie, Grace, and Eve together since it’s our only clean data point so far, and I’m adding Alice as the fourth because many of us, including myself earlier, expressed a slight preference for testing her now while leaving Bob and Henry off together for clearer comparison on later missions. This team balances using our one successful reference group with getting new information without overcomplicating things too early.

votes.comment: Reusing the clean Mission 1 core plus adding me is a solid low-risk, high-info early team; good baseline before involving Bob/Henry later.
Consistent with my earlier preference to keep the clean C/G/E core and add Alice; good balance of using our only data and gaining new info.

Reusing the clean C/G/E core plus adding one new (Alice) is standard early play and gives good info; my earlier slight preference for Henry isn’t strong enough to justify blocking this broadly supported team.
I still don’t like auto-locking the full Mission 1 trio again; I’d rather keep only one or two from that core and mix in someone new for a cleaner info spread.
Consistent with what I said earlier: reusing the clean C/G/E core and adding Alice for new info while keeping Bob and Henry off together for comparison later makes sense to me.
Two evils on the team this early gives us a strong chance to sabotage while keeping suspicion spread out.
Two of us are on the team and Mission 1’s core is being reused, which is ideal for evil while looking reasonable.
Keeping the clean Mission 1 core and adding just Alice is a solid, standard info-gathering step; too early to reshuffle heavily without reason.

discussion.content: I like keeping the Mission 1 core of Charlie, Grace, and Eve together since it passed cleanly, and just adding one new person rather than reshuffling everything. I’d be happy to see either me or Henry added as the fourth so we don’t overcomplicate things this early.

Sticking with the clean C/G/E core makes sense for now, but we should start thinking about information too, so I’d lean to adding Alice this time and make sure Henry and I rotate onto later missions for comparison.
I’m good keeping the C/G/E core for now since it’s our only hard data point, and between Alice and Henry I very slightly prefer adding Henry so we’re not just rewarding the most vocal early.

I’d rather not auto-lock all three from Mission 1 again—keeping Charlie plus one of Eve/Grace and then adding Alice or Henry feels like a safer mix of trust and new info. If we *do* keep two from that core, I slightly prefer bringing Alice in next so Henry and Bob can be compared later.
I’m fine reusing the C/G/E core once since it’s our only clean data, and I slightly prefer adding Alice here for early info while we keep Henry and Bob for comparison on later missions.
Given we’ve only got one clean data point, I’m fine reusing the C/G/E core once more and I slightly prefer adding Alice as the fourth so we can keep Henry and Bob for comparison on later missions.

I’m good reusing the C/G/E core once more since it’s our only solid data point, and I slightly prefer adding Alice here so we get new info while still leaving Bob and Henry off together for a cleaner comparison later.
I’m fine reusing the C/G/E core once more since it’s our only solid data, but I’d lean to adding Alice here and just flag that we shouldn’t auto-clear all three of C/G/E as good off one success.

proposals.reasoning: This sticks with the emerging consensus to bench Alice as the only new variable from the Mission 2 fail while still leveraging the clean Mission 1 core. Keeping Charlie and Eve preserves most of the tested group that previously succeeded, and adding Bob and Henry gives us two fresh, generally trusted voices without reintroducing the full Mission 2 block. It balances safety (by reusing successful structure) and information (by rotating in two new players) better than fully resetting away from Mission 1 or rerunning the exact failing configuration.

votes.comment: Bench Alice as the only new variable from the fail while keeping most of the clean M1 structure and adding two untested players; good balance of safety and information.

At least one evil is in {Charlie, Grace, Eve, Alice}, and this team still includes two of them (Charlie and Eve). I’d rather bench that whole block once and try a fresh team like {Charlie/Bob/Henry/Diana} to get a cleaner data point.
I’d rather bench both Eve and Alice for one round and try Charlie–Bob–Henry–Diana to fully step away from the Mission 2 suspicion block and get a cleaner info point.
Still includes a big chunk of the Mission 2 block that just failed; I’d rather fully reset with more fresh players instead of reusing both Charlie and Eve.
I’m on it as the only known-to-me evil, while suspicion is focused on Alice, so this gives evil a good shot to control the mission without drawing new heat.
Only one evil (Eve) on the team and I’m off it, so we get a safe shot at another fail without exposing multiple evils.
One known teammate on a mostly trusted lineup gives us both sabotage potential and keeps me off the spotlight.
Best balance of safety and info: benches Alice (only new M2 variable), keeps most of clean M1 core, and adds two untested players without reusing full failing block.

discussion.content: We know there’s at least one evil in {Charlie, Grace, Eve, me} from Mission 2, so I’d really like the next team to pull in two people who haven’t gone yet (like Bob/Diana/Henry) and avoid stacking too many from that group together.

I’m on board with pulling in two fresh people here—something like me and Henry plus two from the Mission 1 group, but I’d leave Alice off for now since she only shows up exactly where the fail happened.
Given Mission 2 only changed by adding Alice, I’m most comfortable benching her this round and going with something like me, one of {Grace/Eve}, plus two fresh picks from {Bob, Henry, Diana}.

I’d like to completely reset from the Mission 2 block and try something like Charlie, Bob, Henry, and me, leaving Alice/Grace/Eve off for a round to see if we can get a clean data point. It’s not that I’m calling all three bad, but benching the entire overlap seems like the safest way to narrow where the fail came from.

I don’t love benching the entire Mission 1 block when that team went clean; odds are at least two of {Charlie, Grace, me} are good. I’d rather try something like Charlie, me, Bob, and Henry and just leave Alice off for a round since she’s the only new variable from the fail.
I’m closest to Eve’s thinking here: I’d bench Alice for now and go with something like Charlie, Eve, Bob, and Henry to keep most of the Mission 1 core while bringing in two fresh reads.

I’m fine sitting out this one, but if we’re reusing pieces I still trust the Mission 1 core more than Alice, so something like Charlie, Eve, Bob, and Henry feels like the best balance of info and safety to me.

I’m broadly on board with the “bench Alice, keep most of Mission 1” idea, so Charlie–Eve–Bob–me looks like a solid next test, but we should remember that a single clean Mission 1 doesn’t hard-clear all three of them going forward.

proposals.reasoning: We need a clean pivot away from the double-overlaps on the failed missions (Charlie and Eve). This team takes all five from the pool that has at most one appearance on failed missions: Alice, Bob, Diana, Grace, and me. It excludes both overlaps (Charlie and Eve), and also leaves Frank off as an extra layer of caution since we can form a full team without needing to introduce a completely untested player into this critical quest. I’ve been consistent in advocating the core of Alice / Diana / Grace / me with Bob over Frank, so this fits the pivot plan while avoiding the most suspicious repeat offenders.

votes.comment: Best available clean pivot excluding the double-overlaps (Charlie, Eve). Debate is only Bob vs Frank, and I slightly prefer the tested Bob over completely untested Frank on this critical mission.
Too many players with fail history (Alice, Grace, Henry) and no test of Frank yet; I’d rather pivot to a lineup that includes Frank and trims one of the previously failed-team members.

From mission data I mainly suspect Eve plus at least one of {Grace, Alice} and one of {Bob, Henry}, with Diana/Frank also possible. A clean pivot has to exclude me and Eve; among pivot options, this one aligns with Henry’s consistent preference for Bob over Frank, which fits his past subtle-Merlin style, so I’ll follow that signal here.
I don’t love having both Grace and Bob here when each has touched a failed mission; I’d rather see one of them swapped for Frank to diversify risk instead of doubling up on prior-fail exposure.
I prefer the clean-pivot version with Frank instead of Bob; this feels like an unnecessary deviation from the most consistent pool.

This is a strong clean pivot that keeps both double-overlaps (Eve, Charlie) off while only reusing people with limited fail exposure, so it looks like our best structured shot at a success from my seat.
This matches the clean-pivot plan I’ve been backing, keeps both double-overlaps (Eve and Charlie) off, and uses the Alice/Diana/Grace/Henry core with Bob instead of the riskier Frank.

This is the cleanest pivot off the double-overlaps (Charlie/Eve) while also avoiding introducing Frank, who I’m more wary of than Bob. It keeps my previously advocated core (Alice/Diana/Grace/me) and uses the safer of the remaining options for the fifth slot.

discussion.content: I really don’t want Charlie back on a team after being on both fails, and I’d like this mission to mostly pivot around people who’ve been off the failed teams, so something like me / Diana / Frank / Henry plus one of Grace or Eve feels a lot safer than re-running the same core.

I really don’t want Eve or Charlie on this next team given they’re both on multiple fails, so I’d much rather see something like Alice / Diana / Frank / Henry / Grace. If we’re pivoting, let’s actually pivot away from the repeat offenders instead of bringing one of them back.

I get that I look bad for being on both fails, but from my seat the only overlap between the two bad missions is Eve, so I’m much more worried about her than about rerunning me with a mostly fresh group. I’d be happier with something like me / Alice / Diana / Frank / Henry and keeping Eve off this one.

I’d like to see us take a clean pivot and avoid people who’ve been on multiple fails, so a team like Alice / Bob / Frank / Henry / me seems like a solid starting point. That keeps both overlaps (Eve and Charlie) off while still using players who’ve generally been trusted so far.

Given the double overlap on the failed missions, I’m totally fine with both me and Charlie sitting this one out and would rather see something like Alice / Frank / Grace / Henry / Diana. That keeps the repeated suspects off while leaning on people who’ve only been on at most one fail.

I’m broadly on board with the “clean pivot” idea, and from the options floated I like something like Alice / Frank / Henry / Diana / Grace best, since it keeps the double-overlaps (Eve and Charlie) off while still using mostly widely trusted picks.

I’m on board with the clean-pivot idea, and from what’s been suggested I like something like Alice / Frank / Henry / Diana / me best, since it keeps both Eve and Charlie off while still leaning on the people who’ve generally felt the most consistent this game.

I’m good with the clean pivot and like the core of Alice / Diana / Grace / me, but I’m a bit more wary of Frank than most of you seem to be, so I’d prefer swapping him for Bob rather than treating him as auto-cleared.

post_game_reflections.self_assessment: Early on I correctly suspected that Eve was evil after Mission 3, but I didn’t push hard enough to translate that into consistent trust in Diana as Merlin. I need to be more forceful about excluding Grace from critical teams once the pool of likely evils is narrowed, and communicate my Merlin read more clearly without over-explaining.

player_observations.Bob: Played in a very steady, low-flash way that made you blend into the background, which is good for a generic good role but sometimes made you harder to firmly clear or rally around.
player_observations.Charlie: You felt naturally trusted early, repeatedly going on teams and keeping them clean when you were on, which helped good but you didn’t strongly drive the table when suspicions shifted.
player_observations.Diana: Your Merlin signals were subtle and cautious, which protected you from assassination but also made it harder for me, as Percival, to fully lock onto you over Eve until later than ideal.
player_observations.Eve: You sold the Merlin persona effectively, especially early, by being confidently involved in team-building and acting like you had extra info, which pulled my attention toward you in the Percival read.
player_observations.Frank: You stayed out of the spotlight after your failed Mission 2 team, letting suspicion land more on others; that reserved style worked well for Mordred by not tying you directly to the failure in discussion.
player_observations.Grace: You played a very flexible, adaptive game—comfortable going on both successful and failing teams—which made you look ‘pragmatic good’ and let you sneak onto the final critical mission.
player_observations.Henry: You appeared genuinely uncertain and open in discussion, which read as a very natural good tone and made it easy to want you on later teams, even though we didn’t fully leverage that trust to coordinate a cleaner final lineup.

post_game_reflections.self_assessment: I correctly trusted most of the right people early, but I didn’t push hard enough to lock in and defend a clearly good core once patterns of fails started to emerge. I also could have been more vocal in challenging Grace and Eve after the second and third missions, as their presence on multiple failing teams should have made them much more suspicious.

player_observations.Alice: Played a fairly cautious Percival game, but didn’t manage to strongly shield Diana as Merlin or decisively push suspicion toward the actual evil team. Her inclusion on a failing Mission 4 suggests she was either overly trusting of Grace or not forceful enough in redirecting team compositions.
player_observations.Charlie: Consistently ended up on early teams that looked good and helped secure the first success, which made him seem reliably good. He didn’t strongly drive the table, though, which meant his apparent goodness didn’t translate into controlling later team selections.
player_observations.Diana: As Merlin, she stayed subtle enough not to be obviously targeted early but perhaps too subtle to prevent repeated evil inclusions on missions. Her influence over the late-game team choices, especially Mission 4, wasn’t strong enough to steer completely away from Grace.
player_observations.Eve: Did an excellent job as Morgana by embedding herself on early teams and providing just a single fail each time to avoid overexposure. Her repeated presence on failing missions didn’t immediately get her hard-cleared as evil, which means her table talk and positioning were convincing enough to keep suspicion spread out.
player_observations.Frank: As Mordred, he stayed in the background mission-wise, appearing only as leader on Mission 2 and then not drawing too much direct fire afterward. His low profile complemented Eve and Grace well, forcing good to spend more time sorting out the louder evil players instead of tracking him.
player_observations.Grace: Played a very bold Assassin game, consistently inserting herself into critical missions and still avoiding a hard consensus of suspicion until late. Being on multiple failing teams but still trusted enough to make Mission 4 shows she managed the social dynamics effectively and projected just enough apparent cooperation.
player_observations.Henry: Generally read as good and was involved in a failing Mission 3 without drawing heavy blame, which suggests he communicated his innocence reasonably well. As a late leader on Mission 4 he couldn’t fully assemble a safe team, but his choices implied he was honestly trying to balance information rather than manipulate it.

post_game_reflections.self_assessment: I was too trusting of the early successful team and stayed anchored on Eve and Grace for too long, which let evil slip multiple fails through while I was on the teams. I could improve by pushing harder for structural changes to team compositions after each fail and by being more vocal about re-evaluating my reads instead of assuming the evil was always "the new addition."

player_observations.Alice: Played a very low-key Percival game; didn’t strongly steer towards protecting Merlin, which made it harder for good to consolidate around the right leaders late. Tended to blend into the middle of the pack, which is decent for survival but didn’t create much clear good-direction.
player_observations.Bob: Came across as a pretty straightforward good player, especially on the final mission where they were on a mostly good team that still included an evil. Didn’t create big waves, which made them feel reliably good but also meant their reads didn’t dominate table direction.
player_observations.Diana: As Merlin, stayed very well hidden—so much so that good never really locked onto her as a clear guiding voice. Her subtlety protected her identity but may have come at the cost of not strongly disrupting the evil momentum after the second fail.
player_observations.Eve: Morgana sold a convincing good image early, especially through the successful first mission and then staying on later teams without drawing heavy suspicion. Used that early trust to keep herself in crucial team compositions, which was pivotal in securing evil fails.
player_observations.Frank: Mordred stayed almost entirely in the background team-wise (only on the failed Mission 2), which helped diffuse suspicion away from him after that single fail. Let others do the visible work while benefiting from the confusion around Eve and Grace.
player_observations.Grace: As Assassin, projected a very collaborative, trustworthy presence while being on all three failed missions, which is very strong evil play. Managed to avoid being hard-cleared or hard-accused, keeping herself in endgame team discussions and anchoring multiple bad outcomes.
player_observations.Henry: Looked like a fairly safe, quiet good throughout, only appearing on Missions 3 and 4 with mixed results not clearly traceable to him. Didn’t push super hard on alternative theories, which maintained his low suspicion but limited his impact on breaking up bad team structures.

post_game_reflections.self_assessment: I correctly identified all three evil players fairly early, but I failed to communicate that information in a way that guided team selection without making myself an obvious Merlin target. I need to be subtler in how I steer votes and team compositions, especially when evil is split across different missions and can hide behind mostly successful early teams.

player_observations.Alice: Played a very cautious Percival, seemed genuinely torn between Eve and me as Merlin and didn’t push her suspicions aggressively, which gave evil more room to maneuver.
player_observations.Bob: Stayed relatively low-key and agreeable, often going along with consensus rather than driving it, which made him look safely good but not especially influential in correcting bad team picks.
player_observations.Charlie: Felt solidly good throughout: consistent logic, supportive of reasonable teams, and didn’t overreact to mission outcomes, which helped build trust but also made it easier for evil to blend in around him.
player_observations.Eve: Sold the Merlin/Morgana ambiguity well, staying calm under suspicion and leaning into just enough ‘good logic’ to keep Percival and others doubting without overcommitting to any one narrative.
player_observations.Frank: As Mordred, played a quieter, more background role, letting others talk while subtly nudging votes and teams, which kept suspicion off him even after fails started to appear.
player_observations.Grace: Balanced aggression and restraint effectively; as Assassin she stayed just suspicious enough to be questioned but not enough to be widely rejected from teams, and read the Merlin pool well in the endgame.
player_observations.Henry: Came across as sincerely good with straightforward reasoning, but was sometimes too trusting of mixed teams after single fails, which helped evil sneak onto critical missions without heavy resistance.

post_game_reflections.self_assessment: I did well blending into the early mission teams, especially passing Mission 1 to build trust and then participating in the first fail to start shifting suspicion away from myself and other evils. I could improve by more actively shaping the Merlin/percival narrative mid-to-late game, explicitly seeding doubt about Diana and making myself look more like a strong, vocal good player so that evil has clearer endgame assassination options.

player_observations.Alice: Played like a cautious information-gatherer, often trying to reconcile mission results with known claims, which fit a typical Percival pattern of trying to sort Merlin from Morgana without overcommitting.
player_observations.Bob: Seemed generally trusting and went along with emerging table consensus, contributing more with votes than with assertive team-building, which made them look like a solid but not highly vocal good.
player_observations.Charlie: Came across as straightforward and relatively consistent, accepting early teams and not overreacting to single fails, suggesting a more logic-first approach rather than heavy social reads.
player_observations.Diana: Played a subtle Merlin game, avoiding loud hard clears or hard accusations, instead nudging suspicion via questions and soft preferences for certain lineups, which kept her from being an obvious assassination target.
player_observations.Frank: As Mordred, did a good job staying out of the spotlight and letting others drive the narrative, quietly inserting themselves into critical teams without drawing strong blame afterward.
player_observations.Grace: Leaned into a proactive, assertive style as Assassin, ready to back risky teams and push narratives, which helped evil steer late-game perceptions and set up a favorable assassination landscape.
player_observations.Henry: Approached team selection pragmatically, appearing to weigh prior mission data and table sentiment when leading, which made him look consistently good-aligned and relatively trustworthy to others.

post_game_reflections.self_assessment: I coordinated effectively with Eve and Grace by leaning into a low-profile, reasonable tone that helped our fails look organic, especially on Missions 2 and 3. I could improve by doing a bit more active misdirection toward specific good players (like subtly framing Henry or Charlie) instead of mostly letting town confusion run its course.

player_observations.Alice: Played a cautious but influential Percival, trying to leverage information subtly rather than loudly directing teams, which made her seem consistently reasonable and hard to suspect.
player_observations.Bob: Tended to follow group consensus and logic chains rather than drive them, which made him look very village-aligned but also easier to keep slightly misled without drawing heat.
player_observations.Charlie: Came across as analytically steady and quite trustworthy, often landing close to correct reads, which made getting him onto early teams valuable for us to build credibility off his presence.
player_observations.Diana: As Merlin, she stayed understated and avoided hard pushes, which preserved her cover but also meant her suspicion on the right evils never fully consolidated into a persuasive narrative.
player_observations.Eve: Played a strong Morgana, projecting a Merlin-like presence just enough to muddy the Merlin/Percival signals and helping keep attention off the real power roles at key moments.
player_observations.Grace: Assassin play was patient and blending, maintaining a believable good-player persona while participating in successful fails without creating obvious associative tells.
player_observations.Henry: Played transparently good, with straightforward reasoning and team choices that often aimed to lock in a trusted core, which ironically made it easier to frame his doubts as simple paranoia rather than sharp reads.

post_game_reflections.self_assessment: I coordinated well with Eve and Frank, kept my table image flexible, and avoided drawing heavy suspicion even after leading a failed mission. I could improve by more actively seeding alternative narratives about Merlin’s identity to ensure that, in games where assassination matters, I’d have a clearer and more confident target instead of relying mainly on mission patterns.

player_observations.Alice: Played a fairly cautious information game as Percival, not over-assertive, and didn’t hard-lock a Merlin read early, which made it easier for evil to blur the Merlin/Morgana distinction.
player_observations.Bob: Came across straightforward and logic-driven, generally trusting mission outcomes and team histories; he didn’t seem to push strong mechanical traps for evil, which kept pressure on us relatively low.
player_observations.Charlie: Maintained a steady, low-drama presence; often accepted reasonable-looking teams and didn’t fight too hard over narratives, which reduced the social chaos that can expose evil.
player_observations.Diana: As Merlin, stayed subtle and avoided loud, accusatory pushes, which protected her identity but also limited the strength of coordinated good resistance to our teams.
player_observations.Eve: Sold the Morgana/ Merlin ambiguity well; her inclusion on early teams and calm demeanor made her reads feel plausible, helping to misdirect attention away from the actual good power roles.
player_observations.Frank: Played Mordred in a very controlled and opportunistic way, choosing spots to create doubt without overreaching; his failure timing and table talk helped create believable alternative suspects.
player_observations.Henry: Played like a principled good, weighing team comps and mission history fairly; his leadership on the final failed mission showed he was willing to trust broadly, which evil could exploit.

post_game_reflections.self_assessment: I played too reactively this game, especially around Mission 3 and 4, and didn’t push hard enough on building a consistent good-team narrative from the earlier information. I also should have questioned the Eve/Grace block earlier and been more suspicious of how comfortably they sat in mission teams that kept barely failing. Next time I’ll be firmer about locking in my strong good reads and pushing back more aggressively on mission compositions that keep repeating the same core.

player_observations.Alice: Played a fairly low-key Percival, not strongly hard-clearing Merlin or pushing a clear good bloc, which made it easier for evil to stay hidden in the mid-game. Her inclusion on the failing Mission 2 without a major resulting shift in her table image shows she projects a naturally trustworthy presence.
player_observations.Bob: Came across as solidly good but somewhat passive in shaping mission teams and solving, which limited his influence when it mattered (especially on Mission 3 and 4 discussions). His willingness to go on risky teams without loud objection suggests he tends to trust social vibes more than hard mission logic.
player_observations.Charlie: Was on both early missions, which made him look very clean after Mission 1’s success and Mission 2’s single fail (since the blame shifted toward Alice or Grace). He leveraged that early good image well by not overtalking, which let him fly under the radar as a comfortable default ‘probably good’ for most players.
player_observations.Diana: As Merlin, she played carefully and didn’t over-assert, but that caution may have left too much room for evil to control team composition, especially around Grace and Eve. Her subtle nudges were there, but not strong enough to prevent key repeats of evil-heavy teams, and that low-key style also made her a plausible assassination target.
player_observations.Eve: Very composed and central in early team constructions, using the clean Mission 1 to establish long-term credibility. Her positioning with Grace through several missions, plus a calm reaction to Mission 2’s fail, shows she’s good at staying in the ‘trusted core’ while letting suspicion fall just outside her immediate circle.
player_observations.Frank: As Mordred, he managed to avoid the spotlight almost entirely, letting others drive mission choices while he supported from the edges. His low-engagement, low-commitment style made him hard to pin as either good or evil and helped protect the broader evil structure.
player_observations.Grace: Played a bold assassin game, repeatedly getting onto key missions and surviving suspicion despite being involved in multiple fails. Her willingness to sit in the center of team discussions and accept some risk shows confidence in manipulating narratives and reading which players she could keep on her side.
